doc.previous: There are nine indigenous tribes residing in Guyana: the Wai Wai, Machushi, Patamona, Arawak, Carib, Wapishana, Arecuna, Akawaio, and Warrau.[9] Historically the Arawak and Carib tribes dominated Guyana. Although Christopher Columbus sighted Guyana during his third voyage (in 1498), the Dutch were the first to establish colonies: Essequibo (1616), Berbice (1627), and Demerara (1752). After the British assumed control in 1796, the Dutch formally ceded the area in 1814. In 1831 the three separate colonies became a single British colony known as British Guiana.
doc.after: Since Independence in 1824, Venezuela has claimed the area of land to the west of the Essequibo River. In 1899 an international tribunal ruled the land belonged to Great Britain. The border disputes persist and no final settlement has been reached [10]
